Jonathan Chia Guangrong, Fund Manager at JCG FundLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 12 Oct 20185 cents can mean a couple of things to me in the world of options trading. I can earn 5 bucks per contract, or I can close a position for 5 cents or less and not pay any commission with my broker.That said, for physical 5 cent coins here, you can collect and use up to S$2 worth of such coins in any 1 tranactionhttps://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/what-you-should-know-about-mas-proposed-new-legal-tender-limit-for-coins0 comments0
Nicholas ChanLevel 5. GeniusAnswered on 12 Oct 2018Hard to use 5 cents, gets rejected or frown upon by stall keepers. 0 comments0

Gabriel LeeLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 12 Oct 2018Seldom see nor use 5 cent coins nowadays, but it is still considered legal tender. It doesn't mean a lot to me and if I happen to purchase something which gives a change consisting of 5 cents, I'll probably just ask the cashier to keep it (keep the change)0 comments0

HC Tang, Financial Enthusiast, Budgeting at The SocietyLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 12 Oct 2018Still means a medium of exchange to me. I'll collect and consolidate 2 x 5c and use it as $0.10 to buy food with the rest of the change. Somehow,  I still it as when no choice collecting them, and one shot spend out with the 10c, 20c, 50c and spend it together in a dollar gives me some form or relations because i knew I have :​1) Off load the heavy coins in my pocket2) save some cash in my wallet ​So it feels good! :) haha! Try it to know :) 0 comments0

Good Day Every DayLevel 6. MasterUpdated on 07 Jun 20195 cent is still money even though it does not mean much nowadays. However, would I pick up a 5 cent on the floor? Most likely no unless I am very broke. 1 comment0
Leong Wen Fong12 Oct 2018Hahaha, yea, and to add on, some places even have a limit of how many 5cent coins they are willing accept per transaction
